prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the sensitivity by using the Galactic planetary nebula (PN) M1-16 as model. We chose M1-16 since it has a rich molecular envelope with 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) observations, and since it is unresolved we can estimate flux densities. The radio continuum flux density is 28 mJy at 5 GHz. Assuming optically thin free-free emission we estimate a 330 GHz flux density of 18 mJy. The peak 13CO(3-2) intensity is 37.8 Jy. We scale these intensities to the LMC by the inverse distance squared using a distance to M1-16 of 1.8 kpc and to the LMC of 48.1 kpc. This yields a radio continuum flux density of 0.025 mJy and a 13CO(3-2) peak flux density of 53 mJy. This is not a detection experiment---we need to measure the integrated flux density. We therefore desire a signal-to-noise ratio of 10. Typical PNe CO line widths are 25 km/s, so we assume a velocity resolution of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation.
Generating high quality images would be a bonus for this project but it is not necessary to achieve the science goals. We only need to derive accurate 12C/13C ratios.
We configured the correlator to simultaneously tune to the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) transitions. Bandwidths of 468.75 MHz were selected since they provided us with a velocity range of about 400 km/s, sufficient to cover differences in the velocity for different PNe. This allows us to use the same calibration setup for all sources. We also setup 2 GHz continuum windows near each CO transition to measure the continuum emission. This is not critical to the science goals but a bonus.
There are no special scheduling or observing constraints. The standard calibration should be sufficient. Since the ON source time is a few minutes we are dominated by overhead but not by much more than about 50%.

We estimate the sensitivity by using the Galactic planetary nebula (PN) M1-16 as model. We chose M1-16 since it has a rich molecular envelope with 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) observations, and since it is unresolved we can estimate flux densities. The radio continuum flux density is 28 mJy at 5 GHz. Assuming optically thin free-free emission we estimate a 330 GHz flux density of 18 mJy. The peak 13CO(3-2) intensity is 37.8 Jy. We scale these intensities to the SMC by the inverse distance squared using a distance to M1-16 of 1.8 kpc and to the SMC of 60.6 kpc. This yields a radio continuum flux density of 0.016 mJy and a 13CO(3-2) peak flux density of 33 mJy. This is not a detection experiment---we need to measure the integrated flux density. We therefore desire a signal-to-noise ratio of 10. Typical PNe CO line widths are 25 km/s, so we assume a velocity resolution of 5 km/s for the sensitivity calculation.
Generating high quality images would be a bonus for this project but it is not necessary to achieve the science goals. We only need to derive accurate 12C/13C ratios.
We configured the correlator to simultaneously tune to the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) transitions. Bandwidths of 468.75 MHz were selected since they provided us with a velocity range of about 400 km/s, sufficient to cover differences in the velocity for different PNe. This allows us to use the same calibration setup for all sources. We also setup 2 GHz continuum windows near each CO transition to measure the continuum emission. This is not critical to the science goals but a bonus.
There are no special scheduling or observing constraints. The standard calibration should be sufficient. Since the ON source time is a few minutes we are dominated by overhead but not by much more than about 50%.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We plan to use ALMA to provide a fundamental test of the theory of the evolution of Sun-like stars by measuring the 12C/13C ratio in 23 Magellanic Cloud (MC) planetary nebulae (PNe) using the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) transitions. For over 30 years it has been clear that standard stellar evolution theory is incomplete. Abundance anomalies in red giant branch stars indicate that extra elemental processing is occurring. For many years various rotationally induced mixing mechanisms were suggested but these all proved insufficient when the physics was rigorously included. Only recently has a physically motivated mechanism, thermohaline mixing, been found. Because the distances to the MCs are known we can derive much more accurate progenitor masses. Knowing this, the derived 12C/13C abundance ratios will be used to directly measure if extra mixing is occurring in a statistically significant sample of PN. Only ALMA has the requisite sensitivity to uniquely test this new theory. This would provide for the first time a complete understanding of how stars like the Sun evolve to enrich the interstellar gas with the elements needed to make Earth like planets and to form life itself.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Radio Infrared and Optical Sensors, Naval Research Laboratory
Institute for Astrophysical Research, Boston University
